title: Turning away immigrants isn't just morally wrong, it's not in our interests
text:
Turning away immigrants isn't just morally wrong, it's not in our interests Journal business editor Graeme Whitfield on how the positive benefits of immigration are being ignored Share Get business   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
Last week I went to Merz Court, a building at Newcastle University where lots of clever people are doing lots of clever things. 
The building is named after the son of a German immigrant who invented the National Grid on Tyneside, so it is fitting that the researchers in Merz Court are now working on developing a ‘smart grid’ for the 21st century, looking at how electric cars can help smooth out the peaks and troughs of power coming from renewable energy sources. 
It was fitting too that I was shown around this project by a German academic who pointed out European, African and Chinese researchers working alongside a number of English scientists. 
This multi-national laboratory is not unique. 
Many tech companies in the North East similarly call on skilled staff from around the world, while one has only to have been ill or on holiday in the last few years to know how the NHS and our tourism industry are utterly reliant on migrant labour. 
It is fairly obvious that many people in Britain think immigration is too high and that that is a major factor affecting the way they are voting. Former Chancellor George Osborne made much that point this week when he said that the Government was putting immigration control ahead of the economy in its stance on Brexit . Read More 'I voted against Brexit because it would be bad for the North East' 
But the debate on immigration seems to ignore of all the positives of free movement: the academics trying to make the world a better place, the companies who grow because they can attract the right skills, the fact that you are much more likely to be treated by a foreigner than behind one in the queue at our hospitals. 
Recently a report by the Federation of Small Businesses quoted a construction company owner who said: “If I didn’t have access to my non-UK workforce I would close down. It wouldn’t be possible to operate without my European staff.” 
And this is the key thing about migrant workers. They are not ‘coming over here and taking our jobs’ as some people unthinkingly say. They are coming over here and supporting our jobs by keeping our employers in business. 
I find it impossible, on a purely moral basis, to tell people who have come to Britain to make a better life for them and their families, that they’re not welcome. 
What is slightly heartbreaking is that, even if you are completely hard-hearted about their foreigners in our communities, turning them away will harm our self-interests too. 
Graeme Whitfield is business editor of The Journal Like us on Facebook
